Developing tools to personalize integration efforts in the refugee context.

In 2016, Berlin, Germany saw mass migration of displaced individuals from the middle-east because of wars that we are all aware of. It was in this context that I went to Berlin, to understand the situation better, and try and answer 2 questions— What does integrating into an alien society mean for a person? And can design thinking tools be used to catalyse this integration?

What followed over the next 5 months was an immersion into the lives of the refugee community in Berlin, as well as, that of the various people & organisations who had set up various initiatives to help the newcomers settle into their new lives in Berlin.

Of the many learnings that came out of this, one insight particularly stuck out— Although there were several organisations in Berlin, tending to the many social, emotional, legal and financial needs of these newcomers, information about these initiatives wouldn’t always reach them. Making this the focus of my work, I designed an information dispensation service model, of which, the ‘re:boot workshop’ was a critical touchpoint. The workshop toolkit was piloted at the time, and developed a bit further in partnership with some local organisations.

Unfortunately the project was stalled due to an unplanned departure from the country. However, the project case study & workshop toolkit linger on in the form of a website, which you can access here: www.rebootberlin.tk.

Duration
5 months (Apr ’16 - Aug ’16)
Project Name
re:boot
Role
Design Research . Service Design
Outcomes
Workshop Toolkit . Research Report . Website rebootberlin.tk
